What can we learn from World Class Sports Coaches?

Weekly Bulletin July 2011

When an owner of a software business considers working with an executive business coach, they need to feel confident that they have chosen the right person to work with. They are seeking to work with an experienced coach with highly relevant skills who can prove they have significant experience in the software and technology sector.

The ideal executive coach is someone who can build a good rapport with their client, communicate effectively, understand the challenges they face and their aspirations, is devoted to the task in hand, is a motivator and mentor, has a positive approach and is always well prepared.

Perhaps an alternative way to look at what makes a successful coach would be to compare an executive coach to a sports coach. The success of great iconic sports coaches, magnified by the media, has certainly influenced many executive coaches over the last two decades.

Take for example Sir Clive Woodward, who shot to fame in 2003 when the England Rugby team won the World Cup in Sydney. When Clive took on the job of England Rugby coach, he had one goal My only goal when I took over was for England to be the best team in the world. His ambition was to become a reality.

Clive Woodward, a very inspiring individual, is known for being tough, strong, determined, motivational, visionary, feisty, a stickler for discipline and ruthless. This provides a good blend of qualities needed to achieve success whether it is in a business or sport. He is also a coach, who believes mental strength is just as important as physical strength. He expects 110% and gets it.

Sir Clive Woodward not only focuses on the team but he puts great attention into planning the personal development of individuals on the basic skills, tactics and strategy of modern rugby. He firmly believes that getting the individual players performance at a world class level is the only way to build a high performance team.

A lot can be learned from Clives approach. Whilst an executive coach can address strategic issues on a business level, they must also have the skills and qualities to be able to work effectively with individuals, providing them with the support they require to face the demanding day to day challenges.

In a technical sport such as cycling, a coach has to work on the mechanics. Dave Brailsford, the Performance Director of Great Britains cycling team won the BBC Sport Personality of the Year Coach Award following one of the most successful performances for the GB Cycling Team during the Beijing Olympics. Dave Brailsford has a phrase which sums up his philosophy, and by which he is coming to be known: The aggregation of marginal gains. It means taking the 1% from everything you do, and finding a 1% margin for improvement in everything you do. As a coach, Dave looks at everything that can improve whether its the bike technology, the rider, the team and strives for continuous improvement.

For small businesses looking for a competitive advantage over others in their sector, the aggregation of marginal gains is a great philosophy to follow.

And finally, a very inspiring football coach, Jose Mourinho is an incrediblysuccessful and motivational individual. He is well known for being a very competitive trainer with a very strong personality. Jose is relatively young which means he speaks the same language as the players, who respect him in every way. He is a great communicator and has the capacity to get the best out of his players at all times. Like a good business coach, Jose pays particular attention to detail in all areas, is very well organised and shows meticulous preparation.

So, when you consider working with a business coach, think about what it is you want from your coach. Although the three elite sports coaches weve featured have a huge range of attributes between them, a high-quality business coach will mirror many of the characteristics of a successful sports coach.

Our Executive Coaching and Mentoring Services have been designed for Directors facing the challenges of winning more customers. If you want to discuss the challenges you and your business face, please contact me for a free no obligation consultation on 01536 771440.
